revision.text:
[[File:Meister des al-Mubashshir-Manuskripts 002.jpg|thumb|right|[[Socrates]] and two disciples from an [[illuminated manuscript]] of Mukhtar al-ḥikam by Al-Mubaššir ibn Fatik]]
'''Abu al-Wafa' al-Mubashshir ibn Fatik''' ({{lang-ar|ابو الوافاء المبشّر بن فاتك}} {{transl|ar|Abū al-Wafā’ Al-Mubaššir ibn Fātik}}) was a scholar well versed in the mathematical sciences and also wrote on logic and medicine. He was born in [[Damascus]] but lived mainly in Egypt during the 11th century [[Fatimid]] Caliphate. He also wrote an historical chronicle of the reign of al-Mustansir Billah. However, the book he is famed for and the only one extant, ''[[Dictes and Sayings of the Philosophers|Kitāb mukhtār al-ḥikam wa-maḥāsin al-kalim]]'' ({{lang|ar|مختار الحكم ومحاسن الكلم}}), the "Selected Maxims and Aphorisms", is a collection of sayings attributed to the ancient sages (mainly Greeks) translated into Arabic. The date of composition given by the author is 1048–1049.
==Biography== The biographical details we have come from [[Ibn Abi Usaibia]]'s ''Uyūn ul-Anbāʾ fī Ṭabaqāt ul-Aṭibbāʾ'' ({{lang|ar|عيون الأنباء في طبقات الأطباء}}, "the History of Physicians"). According to Usaibia, Ibn Fatik was from a noble family and held the position of "[[emir]]" at the court of the [[Fatimids]] in the reign of al-Mustansir Billah. He was a passionate [[bibliophile]], acquired a great collection of books and enjoyed the company of scholars, and above all, he devoted himself to study. He trained in mathematics and astronomy under the philosopher, mathematician and astronomer [[Ibn al-Haytham]] (965-1040). He also associated with Ibn al-Amidi and the physician, astrologer, and astronomer [[Ali ibn Ridwan]] (988–1061). When he died, many heads of state attended his funeral. According to this biography, such was his wife's disaffection through want of attention, she threw most of his books into the pool at the center of the house, and so they were lost by drowning.
==Works== {{anchor|al-Mukhtar}} ''Kitāb mukhtār al-ḥikam wa-maḥāsin al-kalim'' ({{lang|ar|مختار الحكم ومحاسن الكلم}}), the “Book of Selected Maxims and Aphorisms”, can be described as a collection of biographies of twenty-one "sages", mainly Greeks (e.g. [[Seth]], ([[Zedekiah]]),<ref>The Spanish translation has "Sedechias" in place of Seth here. (See ''Bocados de Oro'')</ref> [[Hermes]], [[Homer]], [[Solon]], [[Pythagoras]], [[Hippocrates]], [[Diogenes]], [[Plato]], [[Aristotle]], [[Galen]], [[Alexander the Great]]), accompanied by the maxims and sayings attributed to them. The biographies are largely legendary and most attributions highly dubious.
==Influences== His ''al-Mukhtar'' was a great success in the centuries that followed, first in the Arab-Muslim world where it provided source material for later scholars, such as for Muhammad [[al-Shahrastani]] in his book ''Kitab al-wa-l-Milal Nihal'' and Shams [[al-Din al-Shahrazuri]] for his ''[[Nuzhat al-Arwah]]''.
==Translations== ; Spanish: *''Los Bocados de Oro''; translated in the reign of [[Alfonso X of Castile]] (1252–1284) was the earliest translation into a Western European vernacular.<ref>This primitive text (existing in isolation in several manuscripts) was notably integrated in the story of the journey of "Bonium of King of Persia" went to India to find wisdom and which he write down in ''Las Los Palabras Sabios Philosophers''. Text printed in Seville in 1495, in Salamanca in 1499, in Toledo in 1502 and 1510, Valencia in 1522, and in Valladolid in 1527.</ref> ; Latin: *''Liber Philosophorum Moralium Antiquorum'' by the Italian [[John of Procida]] († 1298), friend and doctor of [[Emperor Frederick II]]. Several early Latin translations appeared as [[florilegia]] and excerpts integrated into larger works. ; French: *''Les Dits Moraulx des Philosophes'' by {{ill|Guillaume de Tignonville|fr}}, chamberlain to [[Charles VI of France|King Charles VI]]; [[Middle French]] from the Latin translation. Of the fifty manuscripts extant the oldest dates from 1402. The first printed editions were made in [[Bruges]] by [[Colard Mansion]] (no date, perhaps 1477), in Paris by [[Antoine Vérard]] in 1486, by [[Jean Trepperel]] in 1502, by [[Galliot du Pré]] in 1531, etc. (Nine reported editions by 1533). ; Occitan: *''Los Dichs dels Philosophes'' from the Tignonville's French translation. ; English: *''[[The Dicts or Sayings of the Philosophers]]'' (1450) by [[Stephen Scrope]] for his stepfather, [[John Fastolf]]; [[Middle English]] translation.<ref>Ms. BL Harley 2266.</ref><ref>''The Dicts and Sayings of the Philosophers''; transl. Stephen Scrope, William Worcester and an anonymous translator; ed. Curt F. Bühler (1941)</ref> *''[[Dictes and Sayings of the Philosophers|The Dictes or Sayengis of the Philosophhres]]'' (1473) by [[Anthony Woodville]].<ref>Translation performed after a book containing the text Tignonville lent by a traveling companion, Louis Bretaylles.</ref> William Worcester amended Woodville's translation and it appears this was the version printed by [[William Caxton]] in his Westminster workshop on November 18, 1477, the first book printed in England, that is discounting [[Thomas Aquinas]]'s [[Apostles' Creed]], (''Expositio in Symbolum Apostolorum'') printed December 17, 1468.
==Editions== ; Arabic: * ʿAbd al-Raḥmān Badawī (ed.), ''Mukhtār al-ḥikam wa-maḥāsin al-kalim'', Publicationes del Instituto de Estudios Egipcio Islámicos (Egyptian Institute for Islamic Studies), Madrid, 1958. *: Before this edition, only the Lives of Alexander the Great and Aristotle had been published: ** Bruno Meissner, "Mubachchir's ''Akhbar al-Iskandar''". ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Gesellschaft morgenländischen'', vol. 49, 1895, pp. 583–627. ** Julius Lippert, ''[https://archive.org/details/4630395 Studien auf dem Gebiete der griechisch-arabischen Übersetzungsliteratur]''. Heft I, Brunswick, Richard Sattler, 1894, pp. 3–38 ("Quellenforschungen zu den arabischen Aristoteles-biographien").
; [[Medieval Spanish]]: * Hermann Knust (ed.), "[https://archive.org/stream/mittheilungenau01knusgoog#page/n78/mode/2up Este libro es llamado ''bocados de oro'', el qual conpuso el rrey Bonium, rrey de Persia]". '' Mittheilungen aus dem Eskurial'', Bibliothek des literarischen Vereins in Stuttgart, CXLIV, Tübingen, 1879, pp. 66–394. * Mechthild Crombach (ed.), "''Bocados de oro'': Seritische Ausgabe des altspanischen Textes". ''Romanistische Versuche und Vorarbeiten'', 37. Romanischen Seminar der [[Universität Bonn]], Bonn, 1971.
; Latin: * Ezio Franceschini (ed.), "Liber philosophorum moralium antiquorum". ''Atti del [[Reale Istituto Veneto di Scienze, Lettere ed Arti]]'', vol. 91, No. 2, 1931–1932, pp. 393–597.
; [[Medieval French]]: * Robert Eder (ed.), "Tignonvillana inedita". ''Romanische Forschungen'', vol. 33. ([[Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München]]), Erlangen, Fr. Junge, 1915, pp. 851–1022.
; [[Middle English]]: * William Blades, ''The dictated and sayings of the Philosophers''. A facsimile reproduction of the first [[Anthony Woodville|Woodville]] book printed in England by William Caxton in 1477, London in 1877. Although three subsequent editions of the book were printed in Caxton's lifetime, of the first of these editions, the only surviving copy carrying Caxton's logo and dated November 18, 1477, is held at the [[John Rylands Manchester Library]].
==Bibliography== * Hermann Knust, "Über den der Grundtext ''Bocados de oro''," Jahrbuch für romanische und englische Literatur, vol. 11, 1870, pp. 387–395. * Clovis Brunel, "[http://www.persee.fr/doc/bec_0373-6237_1939_num_100_1_449197 Une traduction provençale des « Dits des philosophes » de Guillaume de Tignonville]". ''Bibliothèque de l'[[École des chartes]]'', vol. 100, 1939, pp. 309–328. * Franz Rosenthal, "Al-Mubashshir ibn Fatick: prolegomena to an abortive edition" ''Oriens'' 13–14, 1960–1961, pp. 132–158.
==Notes and references== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://archive.org/details/dictessayingsofp00caxtuoft ''The Dictes and sayings of the philosophers'']: A facsimile of the first book printed in England in 1477 *[http://bp16.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/cb41879674t/ Les Dictz moraulx des philosophes (1531)] *[https://www.arlima.net/ad/bocados_de_oro.html Bocados de oro (1495); Spanish] *[https://archive.org/stream/mittheilungenau01knusgoog Mittheilungen aus dem Eskurial, Hermann Knust (1879); Bocados de oro]
{{authority control}}

{{refimprove|date=May 2014}}
The '''Day of Ashura''' in Morocco has been traditionally a day of celebration and joy. Ashura, which is celebrated on the tenth day of [[Muharram]] across the Muslim World and is particularly significant for [[Shia Muslims]], where it is a day of mourning. Moroccans however embrace this day with cheerful remembrance of those who passed away. It is a custom to pay visit to cemetery pray for the departed ones.
In [[Morocco]], where the Muslim population is [[Sunni]], the local customs associated with Ashura vary across the country. But traditionally, people exchange mixes of nuts mainly walnuts and almonds, and the popular Dates. Nowadays eclectic variety of Moroccan pastry is added to the mix. Additionally, children are given toys and this is the best time - a week prior to Ashura- to purchase Moroccan traditional musical instruments mainly; taârija drum, Derbouka, Triir and drum tambourines. The night before children play with fireworks in the streets and light bonfire called ''Sh'ala'' ({{lang-ar|الشعالة}}). Traditionally females play with vigour the instruments around this fire reciting traditional Ashura folklore songs. Females then continue to play and sing taking their joy - Nashat- to other neighbours who then join the crowd of players. Marrakech is very known for their Daqqa Marrakchiya performed by Men.
With the modernisation expansion of cities this custom is becoming more and more rare and can only be seen is some traditional neighbourhoods and small villages.
Shia sources allege that these customs may be a legacy of the [[Ummayyad]] rule who sought to time such occasions of popular public display of joy—often pre-existing in local cultures—with the Ashura day in order to humiliate and counter the mourning of their enemies, the supporters of [[Ali]] (Shi'a).<ref name=shia>{{cite web|title=شبكة الشيعة العالمية - فرح النواصب أعداء آل محمد (ص) في يوم عاشوراء|url=http://www.shiaweb.org/v2/news/article_61.html|accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref> The latter see this day as a great catastrophe since it was the day of the death of [[Husayn ibn Ali|Hussein]] and the slaughtering of his family at the [[battle of Karbala]]. However, today in Morocco, the event is not at all associated with the Shia-Sunni conflict and has little religious significance and is seen as merely a folk tradition.
==The Right of Baba Ashur== In some regions of Morocco, the right of Baba Ashur is an activity for children during the festival of Ashura, wherein children wander from one house to another asking for candy and dried fruits or even money and asking the question "the right of Baba Aichore?" of anyone who answers the door This tradition has become famous recently when it has been considered as a substitute for fireworks which usually lead to a range of accidents.
==City customs==
In some cities, Moroccans call the tenth day of Muharram, [[Zamzam Well|Zamzam]] day. On this day, they spray water on each other. Whoever wakes up first sprays the rest with cold water, and gets lots of children and young people out (especially in the popular neighbourhoods) into the streets to spray every passerby with of water. Over the course of the first hours of the morning there are fierce "water battles," especially among friends and neighbors. Whoever refuses to celebrate with "Zamzam water," by sprinkling a little of it on his clothes, may be exposed to a number of volunteers taking turns dumping all of their water on his clothes. Then the day is capped off with a meal of "Moroccan couscous" with dried meat - La Khloua'- saved especially for this day from the sacrifice of Eid al-Adha.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Moroccan culture]] [[Category:Islamic culture]]

{{refimprove|date=August 2007}}
In the late 1950s a number of European countries (most notably [[West Germany]] and France) decided on a migration policy known as the '''buffer theory'''.
Owing to rapid economic recovery in the post World War II period (aided by the American [[Marshall Plan|Marshall plan]]) there were many more job vacancies than people who were available or becoming available in the workforce to fill them. To resolve this situation they decided to "import" workers from the southern Mediterranean basin (including North Africa) on a temporary capacity to fill this labour shortfall.
These workers were invitees of the governments and came to Europe initially on the understanding that they could at any point in time in the future be repatriated if and when economic circumstances changed. These [[Gastarbeiter]] as they became known in Germany were mainly young unskilled males who very often left their families behind in their country of origin and migrated alone as 'Economic Migrant'. They worked predominantly in certain areas of the economy where working conditions were poorer than those of indigenous Germans and where the rates of pay were considerably lower. Ultimately they came to predominate in low paid service rated employment. The situation remained unchanged until the 1970s [[economic recession]].
Jobs were being lost in manufacturing and industry in particular but not necessarily in the occupational types in which the migrants worked. In 1974 the then West German government imposed a ban restricting any future economic migrants and offered the possibility of returning to their country of origin to many others, few migrants took up the offer and stayed at their jobs or began to receive unemployment assistance from the state. This led to increased tensions and feeling of resentment from many German people.
==Second wave of migration==
Throughout the 1970s and into the 1980s [[family reunification]] took place between Turkish migrants workers and their families. This reunification however took place in Germany rather than in Turkey. In a difficult economic climate after the [[1973 oil crisis]] it was generally believed by most Turks already in Germany that their economic circumstances would be measurably better there than back in Turkey at such a difficult time. The [[welfare state]] offered considerable financial support to all people within Germany including immigrants communities. The number of foreign residents therefore increased in absolute terms during this time period.
The German government's offer to repatriate people back to their home country was not very successful. This created a difficult situation for the German government which became increasingly worse as the number of immigrants swelled to their highest levels ever. Any resentment, hostility and bitterness already present between indigenous Germans and the Turkish community became progressively worse. This often culminated in physical attacks on immigrants, arson and overt racial discrimination. There was a feeling amongst Germans that "they have taken our jobs", but this situation only arose because of Germans themselves losing their jobs in industry and manufacturing in particular in the difficult economic situation post 1973. (NB This 'family reunification' corresponds with the second wave on the [[Everett S. Lee model of migration]]).
==Third wave of migration== Dates to the period from 1989 onwards with the collapse of the [[Iron Curtain]] and the communist regimes in Eastern Europe. East Germans flooded into West Germany along with many ethnic Germans from central and eastern Europe. Germany accepted them as they were political refugees and very often [[asylum seekers]].
==Other migration models== *Zipf's [[inverse distance law]] (1946) *[[Gravity model of migration]] and the [[friction of distance]] *Stouffer's [[theory of intervening opportunities]] (1940) *Lee's [[push-pull theory]] (1966)
==See also== *[[Berber people]] *[[Ethnic cleansing]] *[[Foreign worker]] *[[Gastarbeiter]] *[[Immigration policy]] *[[Pied-noir]] *[[Racial integration]]
==References== {{reflist}} * Immigration to Spain: Implications for a Unified European Union Immigration Policy; Laura Huntoon; International Migration Review, Vol. 32, No. 2 (Summer, 1998), pp. 423–450 ; {{doi|10.2307/2547190}}

revision.text:
[[File:Traditional mud cloth.jpg|thumb|Bògòlanfini fabric]]
'''Bògòlanfini''' or '''bogolan''' ({{lang-bm|bɔgɔlanfini}}; "'''mud cloth'''") is a handmade [[Mali]]an [[cotton]] fabric traditionally dyed with [[fermentation (biochemistry)|ferment]]ed mud.<ref name="Rovine 2005">Rovine (2005)</ref> It has an important place in traditional [[Malian culture]] and has, more recently, become a symbol of Malian [[cultural identity]]. The cloth is being exported worldwide for use in [[fashion]], [[fine art]] and decoration.
==Origins and etymology== The technique is associated with several Malian ethnic groups, but the [[Bambara people|Bambara]]n version has become best known outside Mali. In the [[Bambara language]], the word "bògòlanfini" is a composite of ''bɔgɔ'', meaning "earth" or "mud"; ''lan'', meaning "with" or "by means of"; and ''fini'', meaning "cloth".<ref name="Rovine 2005" /> Although usually translated as “mud cloth,” bogolan actually refers to a clay slip with a high iron content that produces a black pigment when applied to handspun and handwoven cotton textiles.<ref>{{cite book|last=Goldner|first=Janet|title=The Poetics of Cloth|year=2008|publisher=Grey Art Gallery, New York University|isbn=978-0-615-22083-3|pages=58–59}}</ref>
==Production== [[File:Bogolan cloth in market of Endé, Mali.JPG|thumb|Bògòlanfini in the market of [[Enndé]]]] The center of bògòlanfini production, and the source of the highest quality cloth, is the town of [[San, Mali|San]].<ref name="Toerien 2003">Toerien (2003)</ref>
===Traditional production=== In traditional bògòlanfini production, men weave the cloth and women dye it. On narrow looms, strips of cotton fabric about {{convert|15|cm|in}} wide are woven and stitched into cloths about {{convert|1|m|ft|0}} wide and {{convert|1.5|m|ft|0}} long.<ref name="Rovine 2005" />
The dyeing (a "strange and cumbersome technique", according to the opinion of J.B. Donne in 1973<ref name="Donne 1973">Donne (1973)</ref>) begins with a step invisible in the finished product: The cloth is soaked in a dye bath made from mashed and boiled, or soaked, leaves of the ''n'gallama'' tree (''[[Anogeissus leiocarpus|Anogeissus leiocarpa]]''). Now yellow, the cloth is sun-dried and then painted with designs using a piece of metal or wood. The paint, carefully and repeatedly applied to outline the intricate motifs, is a special mud, collected from riverbeds and fermented for up to a year in a clay jar. Thanks to a chemical reaction between the mud and the dyed cloth, the brown color remains after the mud is washed off. Finally, the yellow ''n'gallama'' dye is removed from the unpainted parts of the cloth by applying soap or [[bleach]], rendering them white.<ref name="Rovine 2005" />
After long use, the very dark brown color turns a variety of rich tones of brown, while the unpainted underside of the fabric retains a pale [[Russet (color)|russet]] color.<ref name="Donne 1973" />
<gallery> File:BogolanMali32.JPG| File:Ségou (8).JPG| File:Ségou (10).JPG| File:Ségou (12).JPG| </gallery>
===Variants and modern production=== Around [[Mopti]] and [[Djenné]], a simpler method is used by artists considered to be of inferior skill.<ref name="Toerien 2003" /> The cloth is dyed yellow in ''[[wolo]]'' solution, made from the leaves of ''[[Terminalia avicennoides]]'', and then painted over with black designs. The yellow is either removed, producing a stark black and white design, or painted a deep orange with a solution from the bark of ''M'Peku'' (''[[Lannea velutina]]'').<ref name="Toerien 2003" />
Based on these simplified techniques, as of around 2000, large quantities of bògòlanfini are being mass-produced for the tourist and export markets. These fabrics use simpler designs, often applied by stencil, painted in black on a yellow or orange background. With this method, the cloth can be produced about six to seven times faster. The democratic reforms after the overthrow of [[Moussa Traoré]] in 1991 caused many young men to lose their previously guaranteed government jobs and scholarships. This led many to take up bògòlanfini production. Consequently, most cloth is now produced by men rather than women, and the traditional year-long apprenticeships have been replaced by short, informal training sessions.<ref name="Toerien 2003" />
==Cultural significance== In traditional Malian culture, bògòlanfini is worn by hunters, serving as [[camouflage]], as ritual protection and as a badge of status. Women are wrapped in bògòlanfini after their initiation into adulthood (which includes [[female genital cutting|genital cutting]]) and immediately after childbirth, as the cloth is believed to have the power to absorb the dangerous forces released under such circumstances.<ref name="Rovine 2005" />
Bògòlanfini patterns are rich in cultural significance, referring to historical events (such as a famous battle between a Malian warrior and the French), crocodiles (significant in Bambara mythology) or other objects, mythological concepts or [[proverb]]s.<ref name="Rovine 2005" /> Since about 1980, Bògòlanfini has become a symbol of Malian cultural identity and is being promoted as such by the Malian government.<ref name="Rovine 2005" />
==Uses== Bògòlanfini has become a popular Malian export, notably to the United States. There, it is marketed as "mud cloth", either as a symbol of [[African American culture]] or as a generically "ethnic" decorative cloth.<ref name="Rovine 2005" />
===In fashion=== [[File:Mudcloth-005.jpg|thumb|upright|A Bogolanfini shirt (''[[dashiki]]'')]] In Mali, the cloth is worn by people of all ethnicities, including prominently in Malian cinema and by Malian musicians, either as an expression of national or ethnic identity or as a fashion statement. Particularly popular among young people, Bògòlanfini is made into a wide range of clothes, Western miniskirts and jackets as well as traditional flowing robes (''[[boubou (clothing)|boubou]]s'').<ref name="Rovine 2005" />
The Malian [[fashion designer]] [[Chris Seydou]] has been credited with popularizing bògòlanfini in international fashion.<ref name="Rovine 2005" />
===In art=== Bògòlanfini is also produced as [[fine art]] by several Malian artists, notably by the ''[[Groupe Bogolan Kasobané]]'', six artists collaborating since 1978. These paintings are produced with vegetable dyes and mud, but often feature designs unrelated to those of traditional fabrics; their newer motifs are also often found on clothing.<ref name="Toerien 2003" /> Other notable creators include [[Nakunte Diarra]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://africa.si.edu/collections/view/people/asitem/person@ARTIST:D/2?t:state:flow=53ab65e1-b894-4c91-ba9a-3d3fb483cfb2|title=Collections - National Museum of African Art|website=africa.si.edu|accessdate=18 September 2018}}</ref>
Traditional Bògòlanfini designs are also used for on a wide range of commercial products, such as coffee mugs, curtains, towels, sheets, book covers and wrapping paper.<ref name="Toerien 2003" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *{{cite journal|last=Donne|first=J.B.|title=Bogolanfini: A Mud-Painted Cloth from Mali|journal=[[Man (journal)|Man]]|year=1973|volume=8|issue=1|jstor=2800615}} *{{cite book|last=Rovine|first=Victoria L. |title=Encyclopedia of Clothing and Fashion|year=2005|volume=1|publisher=[[Thomson Gale]]|isbn=0-684-31394-4|pages=149–150|editor=Steele, Valerie|chapter=Bogolan}} *{{cite journal|last=Toerien|first=Elsje S|title=Mud cloth from Mali: its making and use|journal=Journal of Family Ecology and Consumer Sciences |year=2003|volume=31|pages=52–57|url=http://ajol.info/index.php/jfecs/article/viewFile/52840/41441|issn=0378-5254}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book|last1=Hilu|first1=Sam|last2=Hersey|first2=Irwin|title=Bogolanfini Mud Cloth|year=2005|publisher=Schiffer Publishing Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7643-2187-0|location=Atglen, Pa.}} *{{cite journal|last1=Imperato|first1=Pascal James|last2=Shamir|first2=Marli|title=Bokolanfini: Mud Cloth of the Bamana of Mali |journal=[[African Arts (journal)|African Arts]]|year=1970|volume=3|issue=4|pages=32–41, 80|doi=10.2307/3345905}} *{{cite journal|last=Rovine|first=Victoria|title=Bogolanfini in Bamako: The Biography of a Malian Textile|journal=African Arts|year=1997|volume=30|issue=1|pages=40–51+94–96 |jstor=3337471}}
==External links== {{commons category|Bogolan}} *{{cite web|title=Discovering Mudcloth|url=http://www.mnh.si.edu/africanvoices/mudcloth/index_flash.html|publisher=[[National Museum of Natural History]]|accessdate=}} *{{cite web |last=Enderle |first=Melissa |title=Bogolan Cloth: images of the production process |url=http://homepage.mac.com/melissaenderle/mali/pages/bogolan.html |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091005012030/http://homepage.mac.com/melissaenderle/mali/pages/bogolan.html |archivedate=2009-10-05 |df= }} *{{cite web|last=Hager|first=Liz|title=Malian Bogolanfini and Cultural Identity|url=http://venetianred.net/2010/03/01/malian-bogolanfini-and-cultural-identity/|work=Venetian Red|accessdate=|date=March 1, 2010}}

Hoshang Yazdegardi &
Family | previous-owner = | chef = | head-chef = | food-type = | dress-code = None | rating = | street-address = Metro House,
Shahid Bhagat Singh Road,
[[Colaba Causeway]] | city = [[Mumbai]] | county = | state = [[Maharashtra]] | postcode = 400005 | country = {{flag|India}} | coordinates = {{coord|18.924158|72.832126|type:landmark|display=inline}} | seating-capacity = | reservations = | other-locations = None | other-information = Open daily: 0800 to 2400 Hrs | website = }} '''Cafe Mondegar''' ([[Also known as|a.k.a.]] '''Café Mondegar''' and '''Mondy's''') is amongst the first (along with [[Leopold Cafe]]) and most iconic restaurant and bars in [[Mumbai]], [[India]]. Cafe Mondegar is the first restaurant in [[Mumbai]] to house a [[jukebox]]. The restaurant is a popular landmark and touristic attraction of Mumbai. Famous Indian cartoonist and painter [[Mario Miranda]] painted [[mural]]s (his cartoons) on all inner walls and entrance ceiling of the restaurant.{{cite news|title=Mumbai's most legendary|publisher=CNN|url=http://travel.cnn.com/mumbai/none/pub-crawl-born-and-bred-mumbai-bars-108539}}{{cite news|title=Cafe Mondegar cartoon|publisher=Tripadvisor|url=http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/LocationPhotoDirectLink-g304554-d810909-i89276863-Cafe_Mondegar-Mumbai_Bombay_Maharashtra.html}}{{cite news|title=Cafe Mondegar review|publisher=[[Lonely Planet]]|url=http://www.lonelyplanet.com/india/mumbai-bombay/entertainment-nightlife/other/cafe-mondegar}}{{cite news|title=Cafe Mondegar remembers Mario Miranda|publisher=Rediff.com|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-cafe-mondegar-remembers-the-man-behind-the-wall-mario-miranda/20111213.htm}}{{cite news|title=10 Meals You Must Have in Mumbai|publisher=NDTV food|url=http://food.ndtv.com/opinions/blog-10-meals-you-must-have-in-mumbai-705431}}{{cite news|title=Cafe Mondegar location|publisher=wikimapia.org|url=http://wikimapia.org/13672/Cafe-Le-Mondegar}} ==History== Cafe Mondegar was started in 1932 by [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrians]] (Parsi settlers in India) as an [[Irani café]]. The current building (Metro House), then housed a hotel called ''Apollo Hotel'' and the café was started in the reception area of the hotel. By the mid 20th century, the café introduced a [[jukebox]], (first in [[Mumbai]]) and was simultaneously converted into a restaurant. By the 1990s, Cafe Mondegar was refurbished, [[Mario Miranda]]'s [[mural]]s were painted on the walls & ceiling, and the restaurant was converted into a bar. Café is owned by Yazdegardi family and Rusi Yazdegardi / Hoshang Yazdegardi are the Managing partners of the business.{{cite news|title=Mumbai's Parsi Café Culture|publisher=Skift|url=http://skift.com/2013/05/11/mumbais-parsi-cafe-culture-is-a-blend-of-people-and-cuisines/}}{{cite news|title=Café Mondegar may shut down|publisher=First Post|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/bad-news-mumbai-cafe-mondegar-may-be-shutting-down-soon-2202292.html}} ==Location== Cafe Mondegar is situated in the ''Metro House'' in [[Colaba Causeway]], 450 meters North-West of [[Gateway of India]], 200 meters North-East of [[Leopold Cafe]] and 400 meters South of [[Elphinstone College]] in Mumbai.{{cite news|title=Coordinates|publisher=latlong.net|url=http://www.latlong.net/}}{{cite news|title=Location|publisher=Google Maps|url=https://www.google.co.uk/maps}} ==[[Mural]]s== In the 1990s, Rusi Yazdegardi (owner) asked [[Mario Miranda]] to draw [[mural]]s (cartoons) on two opposite walls; i.e. wall adjacent to the main entrance and wall opposite the main entrance. Both walls have different themes. Whilst one wall is dedicated to ''Life in Mumbai'', the other wall is dedicated to ''Atmosphere in the Café''. [[Mario Miranda]] sketched his drawings on canvas before their being rendered on the restaurant walls with the help of students from [[Sir J.J. Institute of Applied Art]] under his supervision.{{cite news|title=Cartoonist who loved to draw|publisher=[[Hindustan Times]]|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/mumbai/mario-miranda-cartoonist-who-loved-to-draw/article1-781069.aspx}} File:Cafe Mondegar bar with mural.JPG|Cafe bar with murals File:Cafe Mondegar, Colaba Causeway, interior wall murals.jpg|Murals on restaurant walls File:Cafe Mondegar jukebox.JPG|[[Jukebox]] in Café Mondegar ==See also== {{commonscat|Cafe Mondegar}} * [[Irani café]] * [[Leopold Cafe]] * [[Mario Miranda]] {{Portal bar|India|Mumbai|Food}} {{Geographic location |Centre = '''Cafe Mondegar ''' |North = [[Elphinstone College]] |Northeast = [[Regal Cinema]] |East = MEPS building |Southeast = [[Gateway of India]] |South = [[The Taj Mahal Palace Hotel]] |Southwest = [[Leopold Cafe]] |West = [[National Centre for the Performing Arts (India)|NCPA]] |Northwest = [[Oval Maidan]] }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Mumbai topics}} {{Tourist attractions in Mumbai}} [[Category:Coffee houses of India]] [[Category:Restaurants in Mumbai]] [[Category:1932 establishments in India]] [[Category:Murals]] [[Category:Murals in India]] [[Category:Murals by city]]

revision.comment: RA0808 moved page [[Canadian osteopathic medical student association]] to [[Canadian Osteopathic Medical Student Association]]: caps
revision.text:
{{Primary sources|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox Organization | name = Canadian Osteopathic Medical Student Association (COMSA) | image = | industry = [[Medicine]]
[[Orthopedicl]] | abbreviation = COMSA | formation = 2011 | location = Canada | company_type = | num_members = | website = {{URL|http://www.studentdo.ca}} }} The '''Canadian Osteopathic Medical Student Association''' ('''COMSA''') is a student body that works to promote awareness of [[Osteopathic medicine in Canada|Osteopathic Medicine in Canada]] both among the general population and the future physicians of Canada.http://www.studentdo.ca/#!about_us/cjg9 They are affiliated with the [[Canadian Osteopathic Association]]. == History == Founded in 2011, COMSA has worked to increase awareness of the [[Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine]] degree throughout Canada.http://jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2291220 The organization has helped hundreds of students through the process of becoming an osteopathic physician and has drastically grown in size every single year. Since 2012, COMSA started to host webinars and seminars at various universities across Canada to increase awareness of the DO medical degree. Additionally, Michigan State University College of Osteopathic Medicine (MSU-COM) launched a Canadian initiative to recruit 20-25 Canadian applicants each year to help spread awareness of the DO degree, leading to more than doubling of Canadian applicants and matriculates to Osteopathic medical schools (AACOM data). In 2015, under the leadership of Sevan Evren and Pranay Chander, COMSA conducted a study to determine the priorities and challenges faced by Canadian DO students and ways in which the profession can be expanded in Canada.http://jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2291220 Over the years COMSA has lobbied the American Osteopathic Association (AOA), American Association of Colleges of Osteopathic Medicine (AACOM) and Health Canada to support the interests of osteopathic physicians in Canada. Within recent years, COMSA has established pre-osteopathic medicine societies in Canada at The University of Guelph and Western University. COMSA also continues to lobby provincial regulatory bodies for unrestricted licensure and title protection of physicians with a Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine degree from the US. == Mission == The Canadian Osteopathic Medical Student Association (COMSA) is dedicated to growing and spreading awareness of Osteopathic Medicine throughout Canada. Goals of the organization range from health care policy advocacy, to title protection rights, to assisting applicants strengthen their applications.http://www.studentdo.ca/#!about_us/cjg9 == Executives == === Past Presidents === 2015- Pranay Chander ([[Michigan State University|MSU-COM]]) and Sevan Evren ([[Lincoln Memorial University|LMU-DCOM]]) 2014- Nick Church ([[University of New England College of Osteopathic Medicine|UNE-COM]]) and Iain Jeffrey ([[Touro College of Osteopathic Medicine|TouroNY-COM]]) 2013- Dennis Fiddler ([[Nova Southeastern University|NSU-COM]]) === President === * Ravi Uppal - [[Nova Southeastern University|NSUCOM]] === Vice President === * Corey Mayer - [[Lincoln Memorial University|LMU-DCOM]] === Director of Social Media === * [[Khashayar Farzam]] - [[University of New England (United States)|UNECOM]] === Secretary === * Bianca Zapanta - [[Touro College of Osteopathic Medicine|Touro-COM]] === Director of Canadian Residencies === * Trevor Gill - [[Touro College of Osteopathic Medicine|Touro-COM]] === Director of US Residencies === * Amit Singh - [[Kansas City University of Medicine and Biosciences|KCUMB]] === Director of Pre-DO Societies === * PJ Parmar - [[Kansas City University of Medicine and Biosciences|KCUMB]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.studentdo.ca Official Website] * https://www.facebook.com/CanadianDO [[Category:Osteopathic medicine]] [[Category:Students]]

[[Image:VshSenateSofa.JPG|thumb|This [[Rococo Revival]] canapé delivered to the [[Vermont State House]] in 1859 would have been called a "settee"]]
A '''canapé''' is a piece of [[furniture]] similar to a [[couch]], and is meant to describe an elegant sofa made out of elaborately carved wood with wooden legs, and upholstered seats, back, and armrests that seats three, that emerged from [[France]] in the 18th century. A style created during the [[Louis XV]] and [[Louis XVI]] periods, similar yet different from designs used by [[Thomas Chippendale]], it later became popular in the [[United States]] during the 19th century.
Its shape is distinct from other sofas of the period, including the [[divan (furniture)|divan]] and [[chaise longue]], but does include several forms. Frequently matching chairs were made to go with it. Precious hardwoods such as [[walnut]], [[cherry]], and [[mahogany]] were often used in its construction.
Currently the term is used in world [[furniture]] [[design]] and retail as a variation on "[[couch|sofa]]", except when [[antiques]] or reproductions of 18th century designs are concerned.
==References== * http://www.sil.si.edu/DigitalCollections/Art-Design/garde-meuble/intro.htm
{{DEFAULTSORT:Canape (furniture)}} [[Category:Couches]] [[Category:Furniture]]
{{furniture-stub}}
[[fr:Canapé]]

[[File:Museo delle porcellane di Firenze, secondo servizio di elisa baciocchi, sevres, 1809-1810 01.JPG|thumb|A Sèvres dinner-service on display at the Museo delle porcellane di Firenze.]] [[File:GladstonePotteryMuseum(ValVannet)Jul2004.jpg|thumb|The [[Gladstone Pottery Museum]].]] A '''ceramics museum''' is a [[museum]] wholly or largely devoted to [[ceramic]]s, usually [[ceramic art]]. Its collections may also include [[glass]] and [[Vitreous enamel|enamel]], but typically concentrate on [[pottery]], including [[porcelain]]. Most national collections are in a more general museum covering all of [[the arts]], or just the [[decorative arts]]. However, there are a number of specialized ceramics museums, with some focusing on the ceramics of just one country, region or manufacturer. Others have international collections, which may be centered on ceramics from Europe or East Asia or have a more global emphasis.
Outstanding major ceramics collections in general museums include [[Collections of the Palace Museum#Ceramics|The Palace Museum, Beijing]], with 340,000 pieces,<ref>[http://www.chinaculture.org/classics/2009-02/16/content_322071.htm ChinaCulture.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303200546/http://www.chinaculture.org/classics/2009-02/16/content_322071.htm |date=2016-03-03 }}</ref> and the [[National Palace Museum]] in [[Taipei city]], Taiwan (25,000 pieces);<ref>[http://www.npm.gov.tw/en/about/objects.htm National Palace Museum website]</ref> both are mostly derived from the Chinese Imperial collection, and are almost entirely of pieces from China. In London, the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] (over 75,000 pieces, mostly after 1400 CE) and [[British Museum]] (mostly before 1400 CE) have very strong international collections. The [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York and [[Freer Gallery of Art]] in Washington DC (12,000, all East Asian<ref>Peterson, 403</ref>) have perhaps the best of the many fine collections in the large city museums of the United States. The [[Corning Museum of Glass]], in [[Corning (city), New York|Corning, New York]], has more than 45,000 glass objects.
==Specialist museums== [[File:Meissen-Porcelain-Saxon.Miners.JPG|thumb|Porcelain miners at the Meissen Porcelain Museum]] [[File:Xian museum.jpg|thumb|The [[Terracotta Army]] on display; view from visitor's gallery.]] [[File:Musée Adrien Dubouché - collections.JPG|thumb|The Musée nationale de la porcelaine Adrien Dubouché in [[Limoges]] concentrates on the local [[Limoges porcelain]].]] [[File:Tehran - Glass ware and ceramics Museum.jpg|thumb|The 19th-century building (formerly the Egyptian embassy) of the Tehran [[Abgineh Museum of Tehran|The Glassware and Ceramic Museum of Iran]].]] [[File:Sevres Egyptian Service.JPG|thumb|The State Ceramics Museum, Moscow: A dinner service presented by [[Napoleon]] to [[Alexander I of Russia]] upon signing the [[Treaties of Tilsit]].]] [[File:Kiln at Coalport China Museum.jpg|thumb|upright|A bottle [[kiln]] at the [[Coalport China Museum]].]] Many of the historic ceramics manufacturers have museums at or very near their factories, sometimes owned by the company, sometimes independent institutions. Among the more important ones, with large collections, covered in the articles on the concern, are: [[Meissen porcelain]],<ref>http://www.meissen.de/index.php?id=237&lang=1</ref> [[Nymphenburg Porcelain Manufactory]], [[Doccia porcelain]], [[Royal Worcester]],<ref>[http://www.worcesterporcelainmuseum.org.uk]</ref> [[Wedgwood]] (now independent),<ref>[http://www.wedgwoodmuseum.org.uk/home Wedgwood Museum website]</ref> [[Royal Crown Derby]] and [[Herend Porcelain]].
Some other specialist ceramics museums are (number of pieces are approximate):
;in Australia *[[National Museum of Australian Pottery]], [[Holbrook, New South Wales]] – Australian domestic pottery, 1500 pieces<ref>http://www.australianpottery.net.au</ref>
;in Belgium *[[Musée de la Céramique]], [[Andenne, Wallonia]] – tells you all about the famous ceramic from the city of Andenne<ref>http://www.ceramandenne.be</ref>
;in Brazil *[[Museu A CASA]], São Paulo, São Paulo. *[[Oficina de Cerâmica Francisco Brennand]], Recife, Pernambuco. 2000 pieces *[[Museu Udo Knoff de Azulejaria e Cerâmica]], Salvador, Bahia. 1200 pieces
;in Canada *[[Gardiner Museum]], Toronto, with 3,000 pieces.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gardinermuseum.on.ca/abtmain.aspx?TopNavImage=0 |title=Gardiner Museum website |access-date=2009-05-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031016103917/http://www.gardinermuseum.on.ca/abtmain.aspx?TopNavImage=0 |archive-date=2003-10-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
;in China *[[Mumingtang Ancient Porcelain Museum, Beijing]]<ref>[http://www.china.org.cn/english/features/museums/125687.htm]</ref> *[[Liuwan Museum of Ancient Painted Pottery]], 38,000 Chinese archaeological finds *The [[Terracotta Army]] are on display where they were discovered near [[Xi'an]] *[[FLICAM]], near [[Xi'an]] is a museum for international contemporary ceramics *[[Yixing Ceramics Museum]], 30,000 pieces, mainly from the [[Yixing]] area.<ref>[http://en.chinawuxi.gov.cn/culture/museum/index_2.shtml Yixing Museum (no. 5)]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
;in the Czech Republic *[[Museum of Czech Porcelain]], [[Prague]]
In Denmark * CLAY Keramikmuseum Danmark, Grimmerhus, Kongebrovej 42, DK-5500 Middelfart. Website: http://claymuseum.dk.
;in France<ref>[http://www.ceramique.com/dyn/musees/ Information on smaller French ceramics museums]</ref> *[[Sèvres - Cité de la céramique]], 50,000 pieces, 5,000 of [[Manufacture nationale de Sèvres|Sèvres porcelain]] and contemporary ceramics *[[Musee de la Ceramique]], [[Rouen]], 5,000 pieces, 900 displayed, mostly local [[faience]].<ref>[http://www.rouen-musees.com/index.php?idR=17 Rouen museum website]</ref> *[[Musée nationale de la porcelaine Adrien Dubouché]], [[Limoges]], 15,000 pieces, mostly [[Limoges porcelain]] also rare pieces by [[Johann Friedrich Böttger|Böttger]]<ref>[http://www.ville-limoges.fr/Limoges/weblimog.nsf/Tous+documents/232]</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.musee-adriendubouche.fr/gb/pages/page_id18319_u1l2.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081229065037/http://www.musee-adriendubouche.fr/gb/pages/page_id18319_u1l2.htm |archivedate=2008-12-29 |df= }}</ref> *The extensive archaeological excavations at [[La Graufesenque]], one of the major production centres of [[Ancient Roman pottery]], are open to the public with a museum on the potteries. * Musée Départemental de la Céramique, Lezoux. * Musée de la Céramique de Desvres, Desvres. ;in Germany *[[Waechtersbach ceramics]] in [[Brachttal]], [[Hesse]] *[[Zwinger (Dresden)|Zwinger]] Museum - the [[Dresden Porcelain Collection|Porzellansammlung]], or Porcelain Collection, at the Zwinger Museum in Dresden<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.skd-dresden.de/en/museen.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2009-05-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019130620/http://www.skd-dresden.de/en/museen.html |archive-date=2007-10-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dresden.de/dmg/en/sights/the_old_city/zwinger.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503111200/http://www.dresden.de/dmg/en/sights/the_old_city/zwinger.php |archivedate=2009-05-03 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1026/is_4_162/ai_92545128/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041111085945/http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1026/is_4_162/ai_92545128 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2004-11-11 }} </ref><ref>[http://www.european-traveler.com/germany/porcelain-in-dresden-and-meissen]</ref> *[[Hetjens-Museum]] or [[Deutsches Keramik-Museum]] in [[Düsseldorf]], 15,000 pieces<ref>[http://www.duesseldorf.de/hetjens/sammlung/index.shtml Hetjens-Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090510155255/http://www.duesseldorf.de/hetjens/sammlung/index.shtml |date=2009-05-10 }} website (in German)</ref> *[[Terra-Sigillata-Museum Rheinzabern]], [[Rheinzabern]], for Ancient Roman [[terra sigillata]] ware made near the town
;in Iran *[[Abgineh Museum of Tehran|The Glassware and Ceramic Museum of Iran]], [[Tehran]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gEca_4iSNCUC&pg=PA106&dq=largest+%22Ceramics+Museum%22&lr=&ei=k0P_SdiXHaqMygTunqS6Dg Lonely Planet] Iran Guide</ref>
;in Italy *[[Museo della Ceramica]], in the [[Picture Gallery]], [[Savona]],<ref>[http://www.museodellaceramica.savona.it/en/]</ref> *[[Museo delle porcellane]], in the [[Boboli Gardens]], [[Florence]] *[[Faenza#Majolica|International Museum of Ceramics]], in [[Faenza]],<ref>[http://www.racine.ra.it/micfaenza/index.htm Faenza museum website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090412092433/http://racine.ra.it/micfaenza/index.htm |date=2009-04-12 }}</ref> *[[Montelupo Museum of Tuscan Ceramics]], [[Montelupo Fiorentino]]
;Japan *claims to have over 500 ceramics museums, public and private, including ones at [[Ibaraki, Ibaraki|Ibaraki]], [[Bizen, Okayama|Bizen]], [[Kyoto]], [[Arita, Saga|Arita]] ([[Kyushu Ceramic Museum]]), and [[Tokyo]].<ref>[http://www.e-yakimono.net/html/ibaraki-daruma.html [[Daruma Magazine]]] by Robert Yellin, (#40, Fall 2003)</ref> The [[Arita Porcelain Park]] is perhaps the world's only [[theme park]] based on ceramics. *[[NGK Museum]], specializing in industrial ceramics
;in South Korea *[[Gyeonggi Ceramic Museum]], [[Gwanggju]] *[[Icheon World Ceramic Center]],<ref>[http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_1_1_1.jsp?cid=268225]</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldceramic.or.kr/eng_2009/museum/main.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722141545/http://www.worldceramic.or.kr/eng_2009/museum/main.asp |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.asiarooms.com/travel-guide/south-korea/incheon/incheon-museums/index.html]</ref>
;in the Netherlands *[[Princessehof Ceramics Museum]], [[Leeuwarden]],<ref>[http://www.princessehof.nl/2007/main.php Princessehof museum website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225213946/http://www.princessehof.nl/2007/main.php |date=2009-02-25 }}</ref>
;in Portugal *[[Museu de Cerâmica, Caldas da Rainha]], Portuguese and other ceramics, *[[Museu de Cerâmica de Sacavém]], [[Sacavém]]
;in Russia *[[State Ceramics Museum]], [[Kuskovo|Kuskovo Palace]], [[Moscow]], 30,000 pieces, Russian, French and other ceramics from the [[Sheremetev]] collection,<ref>[http://www.kuskovo.ru/ Kuskovo Museum website]</ref> *The [[Hermitage Museum|Hermitage]], [[Saint Petersburg]] - includes the Museum of The Imperial Porcelain Factory and the famous Frog service made by Josiah Wedgwood for Catherine the Great.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/03/hm3_13_0_0.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805090011/http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/03/hm3_13_0_0.html |archivedate=2011-08-05 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/03/hm3_3_2_4b.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322031539/http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/03/hm3_3_2_4b.html |archivedate=2009-03-22 |df= }}</ref> *Pottery Museum, [[Skopin]], [[Ryazan Oblast]], [[Skopin pottery]]
;in Spain *[[Museu de les Arts Aplicades, Barcelona|Museu de Ceràmica]], in the [[Museu de les Arts Aplicades, Barcelona]] *[[Museo Nacional de Cerámica y de las Artes Suntuarias González Martí]], [[Valencia, Spain|Valencia]], with over 5,000 pieces, mostly produced in the region.<ref>[http://www.viamichelin.co.uk/viamichelin/gbr/dyn/controller/Datasheet/ESPV00027E/41104/Ceramics%20Museum?from=DIRECTORY Valencia Museum website]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
;in Sweden *[[Gustavsberg Porcelin Museum]] ([[Gustavsberg, Stockholm]]), the history of the Gustavsberg Porcelin Factory <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www2.varmdo.se/Resource.phx/plaza/publica/pop/porslinsmuseum/index.htx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114004821/https://www2.varmdo.se/Resource.phx/plaza/publica/pop/porslinsmuseum/index.htx |archivedate=2013-11-14 |df= }}</ref>
;in Taiwan *[[Taipei County Yingge Ceramics Museum]]
;in Thailand *[[Southeast Asian Ceramics Museum]], [[Bangkok]], opened 2005, 2,000 pieces of the pottery of Thailand and neighbouring countries.
;in Ukraine *Pottery Museum, {{ill|Novoselivka, Haisyn Raion|lt=Novoselivka|uk|Новоселівка (Гайсинський район)}}, [[Vinnytsia Oblast]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://vinnytsya-guide.at.ua/load/tourists_sites/historic_and_ethnographic_monuments_of_vinnytsya_region/1-1-0-4 |title=Historic and Ethnographic Monuments of Vinnytsya Region |date=5 July 2014 |accessdate=5 March 2017}}</ref> *Folk Pottery Museum, [[Opyshnia]], [[Poltava Oblast]]<!--http://foto.mail.ru/mail/elena_semenova07/244/-->
;in the United Kingdom *[[Aberystwyth University Ceramics Collection]] *[[Coalport China Museum]], mainly [[Coalport China]] *[[Gladstone Pottery Museum]] - working pottery museum *[[Jackfield Tile Museum]] *[[Museum of Royal Worcester]], at the old [[Royal Worcester]] factory site. *[[Percival David Foundation of Chinese Art]], [[Bloomsbury, London]]. 1400 pieces of classic [[Chinese porcelain]] from the 10th to 18th centuries. *[[Potteries Museum & Art Gallery]], mainly [[Staffordshire pottery]] *[[Spode Museum]], for [[Spode]] *[[Wedgwood#Wedgwood Museums and the Museum Trust|Wedgwood Museum]]
;in the United States *[[American Museum of Ceramic Art]] ([[Pomona, California]]), 7,000 pieces <ref>{{cite web|title=American Museum of Ceramic Art|url=http://www.amoca.org|accessdate=12 July 2011}}</ref> * [[Museum of Ceramics (East Liverpool, Ohio)]], 4,000 mainly Ohio pottery<ref>Peterson, 409</ref> *[[Schein-Joseph International Museum of Ceramic Art]], [[Alfred (village), New York|Alfred, New York]], 8,000 pieces, including glass. *[[Sparta Teapot Museum]], Sparta, NC. Newly opened, with 6,000 teapots
==See also== *[[List of museums with major collections of Asian art]] *[[List of museums with major collections of Islamic art]] *[[List of museums with major collections of Greek and Roman antiquities]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Peterson, Jan. ''The craft and art of clay: a complete potter's handbook'', Laurence King Publishing, 2003, {{ISBN|1-85669-354-6}}, {{ISBN|978-1-85669-354-7}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=PAZR-A9Ra6EC&pg=RA1-PA351&dq=%22Ceramics+Museums%22&lr=&ei=PVj_SfHHC5byygTKwcH3BA#PRA1-PA398,M1 Google books] Listing of museum ceramics collections (heavily weighted to US) pp. 396–412.
==Further reading== * [https://books.google.com/books?id=RD0EAAAACAAJ&dq=%22Ceramics+Museums%22&lr=&ei=PVj_SfHHC5byygTKwcH3BA ''An Artist's Travel Guide to the Ceramics Museums of Europe: With Line Drawings Reproduced from the Author's Sketchbooks''], Alexandra Copeland, Artists Travel Guides, 1999, {{ISBN|0-9586098-0-2}}, {{ISBN|978-0-9586098-0-7}} - covers over 120 museums in 19 countries
==External links== * [http://www.ceramic-link.de/icd/pages/museums/museumsindex.htm International Ceramics Directory] –comprehensive list of ceramics collections with links
