page.title: Women in engineering in the United States

revision.comment: /* Notable American women engineers (in alphabetical order) */ Fixed alphabetization and dashes, added [[Lois Graham]]
revision.text:
{{Women in society sidebar}} Historically, women in the [[United States]] have been represented at lower rates than men in both [[science]] and [[engineering]] [[college]] programs and careers. Over time, this pattern has led to a significantly higher concentration of male professional engineers compared to women.<ref name=autogenerated7>Rossi, Alice 1965</ref><ref name=autogenerated8>Polacheck, Soloman 1978</ref> Additionally, this disparity has led to careers in [[Education]], [[History]], [[English language|English]], [[Humanities]] and the like to be seen as “feminine” careers and areas of study.<ref name=autogenerated7/><ref name=autogenerated8/> Some Feminist theorists suggest that these social and historical factors have perpetuated women’s low participation rates in engineering over time.<ref name=autogenerated8/> Numerous explanations and points of view have been offered to explain women's participation rates in this field. These explanations include beliefs regarding women's lack of interest in science and engineering, their physiological inability to succeed as engineers, and environmental factors in women's [[childhood]]s that discourage them from entering science and engineering fields.<ref name=autogenerated7/><ref name=autogenerated8/>
Negative perceptions of female engineers may play a role in explaining their low numbers within the field.<ref name=autogenerated9>Graham, 2005</ref> According to recent statistics, college-educated women are less than half as likely as men to be employed in science and engineering jobs.
Two forms of [[activism]] tasked with raising awareness include both organizations on college campuses and those geared towards society at large.
==History==
In the early 1960s, a President’s Commission on the Status of Women emphasized the need for women to fill a shortage of jobs in [[teaching]], science, and engineering.<ref name=autogenerated7/> In 1960, however, less than 1% of recorded engineers were women. Furthermore, female engineers that were employed were less likely to have obtained advanced degrees in their field than men.<ref name=autogenerated7/> Research has shown that these trends were reflective of both men's and women's dominant opinions regarding women's role in the workforce throughout this period. At the time, both groups largely emphasized women’s roles as traditional homemakers and mothers rather than as serious scientists or engineers.<ref name=autogenerated7/><ref name=autogenerated8/><ref>Pendleton, 1978</ref>
Despite changing political views towards women and minorities during the [[civil rights movement]], college women’s enrollment rates into engineering were still relatively low when compared to men's.<ref name=autogenerated7/> For example, in a study of over 440 college campuses nationwide throughout 1971-72, approximately 17% of polled Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) majors were women.<ref name=autogenerated10>Montinelli, 1976</ref> This coincides with the fact that, throughout this period, there was little recorded formal discrimination in the American educational system.<ref name=autogenerated11>Cole, 1981</ref> Women who actually applied to engineering programs were enrolled at similar rates to men. Early increases in these numbers did occur, though, throughout 1968-78. During this period, there was an estimated 100% increase in the number of female science and engineering majors throughout the [[United States]].<ref name=autogenerated11/> However, it was also estimated that they still accounted for less than 4.9% of such majors throughout this period.<ref name=autogenerated11/>
Despite women’s increasing numbers in science and engineering fields, [[affirmative action]] and similar efforts were implemented throughout the U.S. to increase STEM enrollment rates.<ref name=autogenerated7/><ref name=autogenerated10/><ref name=autogenerated12>Cummings,1970</ref> It was proposed, among other factors, that early socialization by elementary schools and social stereotyping was to blame for this issue. In the mid 1980s, a shortage of qualified engineers was predicted by the year 2000, further instigating efforts to both recruit and retain women in these fields.<ref name=autogenerated13>Freckman, 1975</ref> Existing groups that promote women in engineering: ASCE Task force Committee on Women in Civil Engineering, Extraordinary Women Engineers Project Coalition.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=dKptTDl6eUcC&oi=fnd&pg=PA2&dq=changing+our+world++hatch&ots=bwbqjKQJTG&sig=KktAZNNjtdSF8EqIbchgJKGNvM8|title=Changing Our World: True Stories of Women Engineers|last=Hatch|first=Sybil E.|date=2006-01-01|publisher=ASCE Publications|isbn=9780784408353|language=en}}</ref>
==Statistics and relevant data== [[File:Percentage of Engineering Bachelor’s Degrees Awarded to Women by School.png|right|300px|Percentage of Engineering Bachelor’sDegrees Awarded to Womenby School]] According to the [[National Science Foundation]], overall, women have higher college graduation rates compared to men. However, men disproportionately outnumber women in the number of Science and Engineering (STEM) degrees received.<ref name=autogenerated14>National Science Foundation, 2011</ref> Between 1989 and 2008, the approximate percentages of women receiving their [[Bachelor’s degree]] in any engineering field were 17% and 19.6%, respectively. The percentage increase in the computer science industry displayed was larger, increasing from approximately 10% in 1989 to 21% in 2008.
Concerning [[ethnic group|minority]] ([[African American]], [[Hispanic]], [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]]) women, the percentages of engineering bachelor’s recipients increased from approximately 7% in 1989 to 12% in 2008.<ref name=autogenerated14/> The percentages of minority women with engineering [[doctoral degrees]] were much lower, however, barely increasing from 1% throughout this period. [[Southeast Asians|Asian]] women actually accounted for a lower rate of engineering bachelor's degree during this time period, from approximately 2.5% to 5%. PhD recipient rates from 1989 to 2008 were nearly identical to minority women’s.<ref name=autogenerated14/>
According to the [[National Society of Professional Engineers]] in 2004, there were approximately 192,900 female engineers throughout the country, compared with over 1,515,000 men.<ref name=autogenerated15>National Society of Professional Engineers, 2004</ref> Of these women, approximately 1/3 of them were [[software engineers]] (62,900). Women were also employed in higher rates than men in [[environmental engineering]] (9% to 4%) and [[chemical engineering]] (7% to 4%). However, they were less likely than men to be employed in [[mechanical engineering]] (8% to 17%) and [[electrical engineering]] (12% to 18%).<ref name=autogenerated15/>
In 1999, women made up approximately one quarter of all engineers under the age of 25, whereas they constituted one-twentieth of those over age 49. This age discrepancy has been attributed to women's notable, but recent, movement into engineering within the past few decades.<ref name=autogenerated15/> According to the Society of Women Engineers, women and other minorities constituted approximately 16%-17% of engineering graduate students from 1990-2003. Furthermore, in 2003 approximately 20% (approximately 12,000)of new engineers were women, compared with about 80% of men (approximately 49,000).<ref name=autogenerated16>Society of Women Engineers, 2012</ref>
According to the ASEE, the top 10 colleges producing women engineers:<ref>ASEE Engineering by the Numbers Report, 2016</ref>
# Georgia Institute of Technology # Massachusetts Institute of Technology # University of Michigan # Purdue University # Univ. of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign # Ohio State University # Pennsylvania State University # University of Florida # Texas A&M University # Cornell University
==Explanations for low participation rates==
Numerous explanations have come forth to account for the lack of women engineering majors in college. Historically, women have both majored and remained in college engineering programs at lower rates than men.<ref name=autogenerated7/><ref name=autogenerated8/><ref name=autogenerated22/><ref name=autogenerated26>Corell, 2001</ref> One of the reasons used to explain this trend has been a supposed overemphasis on the traditional "male breadwinner" household model when it comes to organizing families today.<ref name=autogenerated25/> Although the percentage of families organized according to this model has declined considerably in recent decades, many individuals, including women, still see adult men as the primary [[wage]] earners in households where men were present.<ref name=autogenerated25/><ref name=autogenerated27>Seymore, 1995</ref> Even if this is the case women represent close to 60% of university graduates, including biology mayors. [https://nces.ed.gov/fastfacts/display.asp?id=72 IES: What is the percentage of degrees conferred by race and sex?]
Recently, greater emphasis has been given to women’s socialization throughout their childhoods and [[adolescence]]s. Socialized early in their childhoods, girls are said to be raised in societies where science, engineering, and mathematics are largely promoted as “male [[professions]]”.<ref name=autogenerated25/><ref name=autogenerated27/> The [[media (communication)|media]] has also been criticized for giving little representation of prominent female engineers. Instead, some scholars feel the media is guilty of perpetuating [[gender stereotype]]s by representing women in traditionally “female occupations” such as [[nurses]], school teachers, [[housewives]], etc.<ref name=autogenerated22/><ref name=autogenerated24/>
[[Christina Hoff Sommers]] has suggested that subjects such as Engineering may be less popular among women because they do not accommodate some of their typical interests: caring for/interaction with living beings may be one example. This is not necessarily to suggest, with [[Lawrence Summers]], that women are incapable, or less fundamentally capable than men at Engineering, but rather that they tend to be less interested in the subject.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l-6usiN4uoA&list=PLytTJqkSQqtr7BqC1Jf4nv3g2yDfu7Xmd&index=19</ref> The principle strength of this argument is that it explains the phenomenon without drawing tenuous links with difficult-to-measure influences such as 'culture' and 'role-models', but it is also to some degree reinforced by academic consensus, which was identified in the 'Social and Political views of American Professors' paper as 75% in favor of the claim that differing interests between men and women caused the disparity, rather than discrimination.<ref>http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.147.6141&rep=rep1&type=pdf</ref>
The presence of [[role model]]s, and especially female role models, has also been emphasized as a means of increasing women’s numbers in engineering.<ref name=autogenerated25/><ref name="autogenerated28">Seymore, 1999</ref> Women with one or two engineering parents are said to be moderately more likely to major in such a field themselves.<ref name=autogenerated25/> Additionally, encouragement from teachers, [[school counselor|counselor]]s, [[Academic administration|administrator]]s, etc. are all said to positively impact women's chances at moving into engineering. Better high school preparation in mathematics, [[biology]], and [[chemistry]] were also said to better women's chances for an engineering career. However, according to some scholars, the above factors do not occur in a great enough number to compensate for women's current disadvantages.<ref name=autogenerated25/><ref name=autogenerated27/><ref name=autogenerated28/> Thus, generally speaking, it is said that hopeful women engineers will remain largely [[discriminate]]d against and have inadequate resources at improving their outlook unless substantial [[social change]]s are made.
==Socialization and societal outcomes==
===Educational outcomes=== It has been suggested that, due to the social and environmental factors described above, [[high school]] and college women tend to have lower [[confidence]] levels in their mathematical ability compared to men.<ref name=autogenerated7/><ref name=autogenerated22/><ref name=autogenerated26/><ref name=autogenerated24/> Shelley Correll's observations using the National Educational Longitudinal Survey (NELS) revealed that, on average, women who positively assessed their math ability before testing had a higher average score than women who did not rate themselves well. Moreover, [[longitudinal studies]] on both sets of women also revealed that the ones who did rate themselves highly were more likely to subsequently enroll in college-level [[calculus]].<ref name=autogenerated26/>
Goldman later discovered that positive [[math]] assessments played an important role in women's choices to enroll in engineering.<ref name=autogenerated24/> However, other studies have before and since emphasized women’s early life experiences in shaping their career aspirations. Feeling they are not skilled enough to successfully complete an engineering program or other advanced mathematical and/or science courses, some women perform poorly and thus complete a [[self-fulfilling prophecy]].<ref name=autogenerated7/><ref name=autogenerated26/> If at all, differences in men’s and women’s innate spatial memories were reported to account for about a 2:1 ratio of male-female engineers. Instead, in the U.S [[labor force]], there is approximately less than 1 female engineer for every 10 males.<sup>[''[[Wikipedia:Citation needed|citation needed]]'']</sup> According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics for 2011, 13.6% of those employed in Architecture and engineering occupations were women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bls.gov/cps/wlf-databook-2012.pdf|title=Women in the Labor Force: A Databook|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Further studies have also shown that a lack of pre-degree training in high school did not sufficiently explain women engineer's [[dropping out|dropout]] rates later in college.<ref name=autogenerated22/><ref name=autogenerated25/> Analyses of males' and females' grades revealed that, on average, women who had dropped out of engineering programs were either approximately as qualified or even more qualified than their male peers who continued their studies. Additionally, surveyed female dropouts revealed that very few (approximately 9.8% to 11.5%) actually dropped out because they viewed the work as too difficult.<ref name=autogenerated27/><ref name=autogenerated28/> Among their primary reasons for dropping were: loss of interest in the field, the inability to see themselves as professional engineers, inappropriate behavior from male [[peer group|peer]]s, and the highly pressured environment professional engineers worked under.<ref name=autogenerated18/> A phenomenon called "[[stereotype threat]]" may also help explain women's educational outcomes. Because of existing stereotypes regarding women's ability to excel in mathematics-intensive coursework, they are sometimes said to perform worse than they originally would have had the stereotypes not existed.<ref name=autogenerated34>Ceci and Williams, 2010</ref>
===Workplace outcomes===
According to Hersch, a significant number of [[corporation]]s have increased the number of women engineers hired in the past couple of decades in response to [[political]] and social pressures.<ref name=autogenerated30>Hersh, Marion 2000</ref> In addition to their engineering expertise, women engineers are said to bring unique [[ethics of care|caring]] and non-technical problem solving skills along with an enlarged customer support base. Typically preceding these management changes were other policy shifts such as: 1) a company move from heavy to light [[manufacturing]]; 2) a greater emphasis on service and professional jobs; 3) improved working conditions, and 4) a general improvement of women’s status on the job.<ref name=autogenerated30/><ref name=autogenerated31>Preston, Anne 1994</ref>
Overall, however, engineering is said to remain a highly gender-stratified occupation.<ref name=autogenerated9/><ref name=autogenerated16/><ref name=autogenerated27/><ref name=autogenerated30/> Among the engineers currently employed, men substantially outnumber women. On average, men are also said to hold higher supervisory and [[management]] positions than females, whose [[promotion (rank)|promotion]] prospects are usually more limited.<ref name=autogenerated30/><ref name=autogenerated31/><ref name=autogenerated32>Devine, Fiona 1992</ref> This reason, family and child obligations, and [[layoff]]s combined to account for a drop-out rate of approximately 20% among all female engineers from 1982-1990—a statistic over twice of that of men.<ref name=autogenerated31/>
It has been suggested by Crompton and Sanderson that discrimination in high-level technical jobs is actually ''decreasing'' on the whole.<ref name=autogenerated9/> Moreover, they suggest that [[equal opportunity|equal-opportunities]] legislation ensures that men and women with appropriate [[human capital]] are treated equally in recruitment chances. Direct and indirect forms of exclusion were no longer said to be significant in sustaining gender segregation in engineering positions.<ref name=autogenerated9/> Statistically, [[gender pay gap]]s in engineering are actually lower than the national average. In STEM jobs, female wages are approximately 84% of men’s, compared to 71% in non-STEM jobs.<ref name=autogenerated9/><ref name=autogenerated12/><ref name=autogenerated30/> Moreover, it has also been stated that traditionally stereotypical images of engineering as “dirty”, “rugged”, or “manly” jobs are gradually being eroded—opening employment opportunities for prospective women nationwide.<ref name=autogenerated31/><ref name=autogenerated21/><ref name=autogenerated23/>
However, recent evidence suggests that gender discrimination is still a significant issue affecting women’s confidence and performance in STEM careers. According to Logel, interacting with [[sexist]] men may trigger a stressed-induced phenomenon called “social identity threat” in women.<ref name=autogenerated33>Logel, Christine 2009</ref> Women engineers who faced regular exposure to sexist men on the job were said perform worse on aptitude tests than women who weren’t exposed to such individuals. While women who worked in low-[[stress (psychological)|stress]] environments reported higher levels of confidence and [[self-actualization|self-fulfillment]], discriminated women were reportedly more likely to suppress their feelings and/or let their problems go unannounced.<ref name=autogenerated33/> Such behavior is said to be detrimental to both the women engineers themselves and the workplace, where sexist behavior is likely to persist.
==Initiatives to promote engineering to women==
As science and engineering have become more pervasive in [[society]], women's participation rates in these fields have not seen a proportionate increase.<ref name=autogenerated7/><ref name=autogenerated18>Cuny and Aspray, 2000</ref> According to Cuny and Aspray, this may potentially result in a lack of women's [[aptitude|talent]] in the fields, which may further reduce employment opportunities for both employer and employee <ref name=autogenerated18/> In order to make engineering more appealing to young women, a broader acceptance criteria into such programs has been proposed.<ref name=autogenerated18/> Specifically, admissions boards are encouraged to take other admissions factors into account such as: [[extracurricular]] accomplishments, applicants' desire to be admitted into the program, and [[communication skills]]. Additionally, it has been strongly suggested that admissions boards prioritize ethnic diversity.<ref name=autogenerated18/><ref name=autogenerated19>Milgrim, 2011</ref>
Research has revealed that [[high school]]- and college-age women commonly see the STEM environment as a "chilly, male-dominated" environment that is highly impersonal and unsympathetic to women's unique needs.<ref name=autogenerated8/><ref name=autogenerated22>Vrcelj and Krishnan, 2008</ref><ref name=autogenerated21>Morganson and Jones, 2010</ref><ref name=autogenerated23>Bona and Kelly, 2010</ref> "Social [[coping (psychology)|coping]]" has thus been a mechanism which has been cited to help women deal with the challenges and [[stress (psychological)|stress]] associated with engineering's rigorous coursework and careers.<ref name=autogenerated21/> [[Multiple regression]] analysis has revealed that high levels of social coping were a stronger predictor of commitment to staying in engineering studies for women than men. Put more simply, women who used social coping were less likely than men (who were actually found to be ''more'' likely) to drop out of college engineering programs. Consequently, school [[teacher]]s, staff, parents, and other figures have been encouraged to provide a more accommodating environment for social coping.<ref name=autogenerated21/><ref name=autogenerated19/>
An increase in influential female role models has also been cited as a way to increase women's engineering enrollment rates.<ref name=autogenerated23/> [[Survey methodology|survey]]s collected among 141 female engineering students across the country have shown that many women who placed high confidence levels in their math and science ability also had parents who modeled less traditional [[gender roles]]. Thus, to increase women's enrollment and retention rates in engineering, scholars have suggested that a de-emphasis away from the highly popularized "[[nuclear family]]" model is crucial.<ref name=autogenerated8/><ref name=autogenerated25>Haines and Wallace,2002</ref><ref name=autogenerated24>Goldman and Hewitt, 1976</ref> The Society of Women Engineers (SWE) was established in May 27, 1950<ref name=":0" /> by [[Elsie Eaves]] as a non-profit educational and service organization that attempted both to raise awareness of female engineers and increase their enrollment rates.<ref name=autogenerated16/> SWE held their first meeting with 50 engineers at Cooper Union in NJ.<ref name=":0" /> With membership now exceeding 17,000 members in over 300 student organizations across the United States, the SWE's principal aims are to inform female students about opportunities in the field of engineering and to encourage female engineers to attain high levels of achievement.
==Notable American women engineers (in alphabetical order)==
* [[Nora Stanton Blatch Barney]] (1883–1971) - the first woman to receive a degree in civil engineering from [[Cornell University]], in 1905, when she was also accepted as a junior member of the [[American Society of Civil Engineers]]. However, she was later refused the Society's Associate Membership. * [[Gail Boydston]] – Chemical Engineer at the [[Eli Lilly and Company]], holding key hiring and training. Held instrumental role in developing new types of [[insulin]] and other chemicals.<ref name=autogenerated17>Women At Work Museum.</ref> * [[Olive Dennis]] (1885–1957), was the second woman to graduate from Cornell with a civil engineering degree, in 1920. She was initially hired by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad as a draftsman but later became the first person to have the title of Service Engineer when it was created. * [[Denice Denton]] (1959–2006) – Electrical Engineering Professor and Dean of [[University of Washington]]. First woman in the United States to lead an engineering college of a major university.<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Mildred Dresselhaus]] (1930–) – Professor of Physics and Engineering at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT). Awarded the [[National Medal of Science]] in 1990 in recognition of work on electronic properties of materials.<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Bonnie Dunbar]] (1949–) – [[NASA]] astronaut and [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Ceramic Engineering]]. Honored as the Rockwell International Engineer of the year in 1978.<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Thelma Estrin]] (1924–) – Professor Emerita, Department of [[Computer Science]], at [[University of California at Los Angeles]]. Pioneering work in the fields of [[expert systems]] and [[biomedical engineering]]. Recipient of Superior Accomplishment Award From National Science Foundation.<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Bertha Lamme Feicht]] (1869–1943) - First woman to receive a degree in engineering from [[Ohio State University]] and first female engineer to be hired by [[Westinghouse Electric (1886)|Westinghouse]].<ref name="OSU">{{cite web | url = http://library.osu.edu/blogs/archives/2013/12/18/twelve-days-bertha-lamme-was-first-female-engineering-grad/ | title = Twelve Days: Bertha Lamme was first female engineering grad | date = 18 December 2013 | publisher = The Ohio State University | location = Columbus, Ohio}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Westinghouse Official Dies in Retirement | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19490423&id=r9UMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TGoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1711,3086491 | newspaper = Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location = Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania | date = 23 April 1949}}</ref> * [[Lillian Gilbreth]] (1878–1972) – One of the first working female engineers to obtain a PhD. Co-chair of Gilbreth Inc., which performed [[time and motion study]].<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Lois Graham]] (1925–2013) - Professor of [[thermodynamics]] at [[Illinois Institute of Technology|IIT]]. First woman in engineering departments at [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute|RPI]] and IIT, and first woman to receive a PhD in mechanical engineering (1959). Fourth National President of the [[Society of Women Engineers]]. * [[Beatrice Hicks]] (1919–1979) – Engineering degrees in both Chemical and Electrical engineering. Founding member of Society of Women Engineers (SWE). First woman hired at [[Western Electric Company]].<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Grace Murray Hopper]] (1906–1992) – Developed first computer compiler as a research fellow at [[Harvard]]'s Computational Laboratory. Invented [[COBOL]] programming language. First U.S citizen to become distinguished Fellow of British Computer Study.<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Barbara McClintock]] (1902–1992) – Notable contributor to the discipline now referred to as biomedical engineering. First recipient of the [[MacArthur Foundation]] Grant, and is a [[Nobel laureate]].<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Elizabeth Messer]] – [[Aerospace engineer]] at NASA. First female engineer at NASA's [[Stennis Space Center]]. Led a team that developed and tested the Marshall Oxygen Cold-flow Facility.<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Elisabeth Pate-Cornell]] (1948–) – PhD in engineering with an emphasis in [[risk management]]. Distinguished Professor and Chair of [[Industrial Engineering]] at [[Stanford University]]. First female engineering faculty member from Stanford to be elected to [[National Academy of Engineering]].<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Judith Resnik]] (1949–1986) – NASA Astronaut with a PhD in Electrical Engineering. Logged approximately 145 hours in orbit. Died in failed [[Space Shuttle Challenger|Challenger]] mission, and subsequently had the "Judith Resnik Award in Engineering" named in her honor.<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Ellen Swallow Richards]] (1842–1911) – Known as the "mother of environmental engineering." Conducted first water quality studies of [[Massachusetts]] waters in 1870.<ref name=autogenerated17/> *[[Mary G. Ross]] (1908–2008) - First Native American female engineer. She was one of the 40 founding engineers of the renowned and highly secretive [[Skunk Works]] project at [[Lockheed Corporation]].<ref name="AN">{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Jasmin K. |location=New York |subscription=yes |title=Mary Golda Ross: The first Native American female engineer |url=http://www.amsterdamnews.com/education/nie/mary-golda-ross-the-first-native-american-female-engineer/article_64017f68-9250-11e2-8445-001a4bcf887a.html?_dc=410927979042.7536|accessdate=March 29, 2013 |newspaper=Amsterdam News |date=March 21, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130410053149/http://www.amsterdamnews.com/education/nie/mary-golda-ross-the-first-native-american-female-engineer/article_64017f68-9250-11e2-8445-001a4bcf887a.html?_dc=410927979042.7536|archivedate=April 10, 2013|df=}}</ref> * [[Katherine Stinson]] (1891–1977) – First woman to work for the [[United States government role in civil aviation|Civil Aeronautics Administration]] (later become known as the ([[Federal Aviation Administration]]). Named Aviation Pioneer of the Year in 1987.<ref name=autogenerated17/> * [[Mary Barra]] – Barra is the first female CEO of a major global automaker. On December 10, 2013, GM named her to succeed Dan Akerson as Chief Executive Officer, and prior to that, Barra served as the Executive Vice President of Global Product Development, Purchasing and Supply Chain at General Motors.<ref name=autogenerated17/>
==Organizations to promote female engineering== *[[Society of Women Engineers]][SWE)] – Nonprofit educational organization founded in 1950. SWE is the world’s largest advocate and catalyst for change for women in engineering and technology. Membership currently numbers 38,000. *[[Anita Borg Institute for Women and Technology]] – Nonprofit organization founded by computer scientist [[Anita Borg]] in 1997. Institute's primary aim is to recruit, retain, and advance women in technology. *[[Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing]] – A series of conferences designed in 1994 to bring research and career interests of women in computing to mainstream society. Currently a subset of the Anita Borg Institute, and the world's largest gathering of women in computing. *IEEE Women in Engineering (WIE) is one of the largest international professional organizations dedicated to promoting women engineers and scientists and inspiring girls around the world to follow their academic interests to a career in engineering. *[[Robogals]] – International student-run organization that aims to significantly increase the number of young women pursuing engineering as their future careers. Founded at [[University of Melbourne]] in July 1988, and has strong emphasis on [[robotics]] and electrical engineering.
